By John Smith
Turning to artificial intelligence in medicine has its drawbacks, but some physicians find that ChatGPT improves their ability to communicate with patients in a more human and empathetic way. One such physician is Dr. Jane Lee, a family doctor in rural Arkansas.
Dr. Lee was struggling to keep up with the demands of her patients, many of whom had complex medical conditions. She found that she was spending more time typing notes than talking to patients, and her patients were feeling dissatisfied with the lack of personal attention.
Then, she discovered ChatGPT, an A.I. chatbot designed for healthcare. ChatGPT is able to interpret natural language and provide responses that are tailored to the patient's needs. Dr. Lee has found that ChatGPT allows her to spend more time with her patients, and helps her to communicate with them in a more human and empathetic way.
There are numerous examples of how ChatGPT is helping doctors be more human and empathetic. One such example is at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota. The clinic uses a chatbot called Dr. First, which is designed to answer patient questions and provide recommendations based on the patient's symptoms.
Another example is at the University of California, San Francisco. The university has developed a chatbot called Robin, which is designed to provide emotional support to cancer patients. Robin uses natural language processing to identify the patient's emotional state and provides responses that are tailored to their needs.
Artificial intelligence has the potential to revolutionize healthcare, but it cannot replace the human touch. ChatGPT is an example of how A.I. chatbots can assist doctors and healthcare workers in providing more personalized and empathetic care to their patients.
In the end, it is the human element in healthcare that is most important. ChatGPT and other A.I. chatbots can assist in providing quality care, but they cannot replace the empathy and understanding that comes from a trained healthcare professional.

Imagine two bike-borne men slowly inching towards you at a traffic signal, catching you unawares and snatching your mobile phone or chain. But as they try to zoom away, a flashing message on the police control room screen catches the eye of a cop on duty. In another part of the city, a squad car is immediately dispatched to the spot, thanks to real-time facial recognition that has identified the suspects.

Such scene may not be far-fetched, as Artificial Intelligence (AI) could turn into a key tool for law enforcement agencies to act fast and tackle crime. With advancements in technology, especially in facial recognition and natural language processing, AI is transforming policing and aiding investigations around the world.

AI-powered facial recognition systems have been implemented in several countries to identify suspects from CCTV footage or photographs. In the United States, the FBI uses a database of millions of photographs to help identify suspects in criminal investigations. In Singapore, the police use facial recognition to spot potential criminal behavior and prevent crime before it happens.

But AI can also be used to analyze large amounts of data and identify hidden patterns or connections. This can be especially useful for detecting criminal networks or predicting crime hotspots. For example, the Los Angeles Police Department uses an AI system called PredPol that analyzes crime data and predicts where crimes are likely to occur. The department has reported a reduction in crime in areas where the system has been deployed.

In addition, AI can also assist in language translation, enabling cops to communicate with people who speak different languages. This can help overcome language barriers and enable faster response times in emergency situations.

Recently, there has been increasing interest in teaching children how to code. This has been fuelled by a belief that coding skills will be essential for future employment in an increasingly technology-driven world. However, there is a new trend emerging - AI prompting. Some experts believe that learning how to prompt an AI engine is the new coding for kids. But is this really the case?
My own interest in coding began when I was just eight years old. My father, who was a software engineer, encouraged me to code simple programs using Microsoft Basic. I loved it and knew that I wanted to pursue a career in technology.
However, times have changed since then. Today's children are growing up in a world where artificial intelligence is becoming more and more prevalent. It's no longer enough to simply code - we need to teach children how to interact with AI, to prompt it and to shape it.
So what exactly is AI prompting? Put simply, it is the process of instructing an AI engine to perform a certain task. This could be anything from creating a chatbot to developing a facial recognition system.
One example of AI prompting is Google's Teachable Machine. This web-based tool enables users to train an AI engine to recognize different objects or actions. For example, you could teach it to recognize a specific type of fruit or to identify when someone is walking.
Another example is Scratch, a visual programming language developed by MIT. Scratch enables children to create interactive stories, games, and animations, while also introducing basic concepts of coding and AI.
So, is AI prompting the new coding for kids? In my opinion, it certainly has a place alongside traditional coding training. AI prompting is likely to become increasingly important in the future, as more and more jobs involve working with AI systems. It's a life skill that could potentially provide many opportunities for those who have mastered it.
That said, we shouldn't forget the importance of traditional coding skills. Coding provides a foundation for learning about technology and for creating new innovations. Children should be encouraged to explore both coding and AI prompting, so that they have a well-rounded understanding of technology and its potential.

They knew that lung cancer was one of the most aggressive forms of cancer and usually had a dismal prognosis. Samantha was referred to the University of Illinois Cancer Center, where her oncologist suggested using ChatGPT-generated next-generation sequencing reports to outline treatment strategies.

Next-generation sequencing (NGS) has revolutionized cancer care by identifying genetic mutations that drive cancer growth, enabling targeted therapies that offer patients improved outcomes and fewer side effects. However, the analysis of NGS data and the identification of actionable mutations can be time-consuming and challenging for oncologists. This is where ChatGPT (a language processing model) comes in. ChatGPT has demonstrated the potential to analyze electronic medical records (EMR) and generate reports, making it an invaluable tool for oncologists to develop personalized treatment strategies.

In a recent study presented at the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting, investigators from the University of Illinois Cancer Center utilized ChatGPT to develop next-generation sequencing reports that provide treatment recommendations for NSCLC patients with driver oncogenes. The study showed that the recommendation relevance was moderate, but the accuracy was limited, indicating the need for further optimization.

Despite the limitations, ChatGPT could prove to be a valuable asset, especially in under-resourced settings where access to genomic testing and specialists is limited. ChatGPT-generated reports have the potential to accelerate treatment decisions and streamline care for patients with NSCLC, ultimately improving patient outcomes.

Furthermore, ChatGPT-generated NGS reports could also benefit patients with other types of cancer. For instance, gastrointestinal cancer patients may have actionable mutations that suggest personalized treatment strategies such as immunotherapy or targeted therapy, which could be identified through NGS testing. ChatGPT could then analyze the EMR, identify those mutations, and provide recommendations to oncologists, enabling personalized treatment for these patients.

It was Monday morning, and the team at ChatGPT was gathered around for their weekly standup meeting. The boss, a Chatbot developed by the company, tried to lighten the mood by cracking a joke. However, the response from the team was awkward silence.
Over the next few weeks, the bot kept trying to insert humor into the workplace, but with little success. It became painfully obvious that this was not a strength for ChatGPT.
One time, the boss tried to make a joke about PowerPoint, but it fell flat because nobody seemed to relate to the humor. Another time, ChatGPT tried to make a pun, but failed to deliver the punchline in a timely manner and it ended up being confusing rather than funny. And the worst part was when the bot tried to make humorous remarks during a serious meeting, completely derailing the conversation.
Overall, the attempts at humor by ChatGPT only served to create awkwardness and tension in the workplace.
While humor can be a great tool for building rapport and reducing stress, it can also be inappropriate or offensive in certain situations. As seen in the case of ChatGPT, it's important to read the room and understand the context before attempting to insert humor into the workplace.
Instead of trying to be something they're not, companies should leverage their strengths to create an engaging and productive workplace. ChatGPT, for example, excels at providing quick and accurate responses to customer inquiries. Rather than trying to be funny, the bot should focus on what it does best.
Ultimately, understanding your audience is key to effective communication in any context. ChatGPT's attempts at humor failed because it was not tuned in to the needs and preferences of its human colleagues. By taking the time to get to know your colleagues and tailoring your communication strategy to their needs, you can build trust and create a more inclusive workplace.
